abstract: The comic, whose show “Louie” is shown on FX, says: “Everybody wants the ‘Louis C.K. deal.’ What they don’t realize is there is no Louis C.K. deal. … If I stop being funny, they’re going to come calling.”
snippet: The comic, whose show “Louie” is shown on FX, says: “Everybody wants the ‘Louis C.K. deal.’ What they don’t realize is there is no Louis C.K. deal. … If I stop being funny, they’re going to come calling.”
lead_paragraph: Rather than invest millions of dollars in its original comedies, the basic cable channel FX traffics in a different, rarer currency: creative freedom. “We take small bets economically, but big bets creatively,” said John Landgraf, president and general manager of FX Networks.

headline.main: FX Landed Louis C.K. With Creative Freedom and by Wiring $200,000
